conclusion: Shadows are formed by blocking light, and their size and position depend on the distance between the object, light source, and surface.
When the light source is closer to the objects, shadows are longer and more elongated.
When the light source moves farther away, shadows become shorter and more compact.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift positions and move closer to the objects that cast them.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will become smaller because the light rays hit the ground at a steeper angle, reducing the spread of the shadow.
Shadow A (Hat) will move closer to the hat and become smaller.
Shadow B (Glove) will move closer to the glove and become smaller.
Shadow C (Peach) will move closer to the peach and become smaller.
Shadow D (Clip Board) will move closer to the clip board and become smaller.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and will become smaller.
